commentary_central: The Fed wants to wait-and-see before acting. It says it is in a good position to respond either way
commentary_higher: Evidence emerges that tariffs are likely to have more of an inflationary impact that expected and the Fed makes a pre-emptive move
commentary_lower: Consumer confidence and business sentiment weaken rapidly, prompting the Fed to make an emergency rate cut

commentary_central: The Fed holds rates in wait-and-see mode while it assesses the effects of the tariff stagflationary shock
commentary_higher: A clear inflationary shock from tariffs emerges, forcing the Fed to shore up its credibility with a rate rise
commentary_lower: The Fed gains sufficient evidence of an economic downturn and rapird rise in unemployment to cut rates

commentary_central: The Fed continues in wait-and-see mode with some tension between its price stability and maximum employment elements of its mandate
commentary_higher: Tariffs result in a significant rise in inflation and the Fed is forced to raise rates to maintain the credibility of monetary policy
commentary_lower: The Fed has sufficient evidence that the inflationary shock is small and cuts rates, perhaps aggressively

commentary_central: The Fed begins to ease, but it is very tentative
commentary_higher: Inflationary results of tariffs and the US budget require interest rates to stay higher or rise
commentary_lower: Clear weakness in the real economy leads to the faster pace of cuts

commentary_central: The Fed continues gradual path of easing towards neutral
commentary_higher: Inflationary policies require interest rates to stay higher or rise
commentary_lower: Weakness in real economy leads to faster pace of cuts or a lower estimate of neutral rates

commentary_central: Interest rates converge on a rate similar to the long-term trend growth of the US economy plus inflation, although the path towards these rates might be bumpy with long periods outside the range.
commentary_higher: Strong growth or a growing lack of confidence in US public finances requires a higher neutral interest rate.
commentary_lower: Weak and persistently low growth generates few outside options for savings, helping the longer-term interest rate to fall to low levels.

commentary_central: Easing continues and the ECB reduces rates again at the prevailing quarter point pace in response to the tariff threa
commentary_higher: Inflation expectations jump either from retaliatory tariffs or some other extraneous shock and the ECB holds
commentary_lower: Tariffs hit consumer and business confidence harder than expected, unemployment rises sharply and forces the ECB to cut by a half point

commentary_central: Having delivered four cuts in total in 2025 and on the cusp of “accomodative” territory the bar to push below 2 per cent will be high
commentary_higher: Elevated inflation risks keep the ECB holding higher for longer than expected
commentary_lower: The ECB is forced to cut faster as economic data such as unemployment start to show signs of a contraction caused by tariffs and high uncertainty

commentary_central: The ECB cuts rates five times, taking the benchmark at or just below neutral as the European economy slows down
commentary_higher: Tariff impact is less severe than expected and recoveries in consumer spending and investment arrive as expected
commentary_lower: The ECB takes rates well below neutral as tariffs prove a bigger shcok to growth than expected and unemployment begins to rise

commentary_central: The ECB delivers another rate cut after December 2025, keeping the stance slightly accommodative
commentary_higher: The ECB keeps rates close to neutral as a strong pick-up in consumption keeps inflation at target
commentary_lower: The ECB delivers additional rate cuts after persistently weak consumption and an unfavourable international environment raise the risks of undershooting.

commentary_central: The ECB delivers another rate cut after December 2025, keeping the stance slightly accommodative
commentary_higher: The ECB keeps rates close to neutral as a strong pick-up in consumption keeps inflation at target
commentary_lower: The ECB delivers additional rate cuts after persistently weak consumption and an unfavourable international environment raise the risks of undershooting.

commentary_central: Interest rates converge on a rate similar to the expected inflation rate and lower than nominal GDP.
commentary_higher: More potential investment opportunity or an uplift in productivity would require a higher neutral interest rate.
commentary_lower: Weak potential output and persistently low investment generate few outside options for savings, helping the long-term interest rate to fall to low levels.

commentary_central: We expect the BoE to cut in May, maintaining the quarterly pace of monetary easing that started last August
commentary_higher: MPC decides to leave rates unchanged in May, noting high levels of uncertainty and inflationary pressures from still-too-high wage growth and Budget-related price changes
commentary_lower: UK activity and inflation slow in early 2025, leading to fears of stagnation and a rapid drop in inflation without a more aggressive programme of cuts

commentary_central: The BoE holds in June as inflation rises slightly due to energy and regulated prices
commentary_higher: MPC decides to slow rate cuts in 2025 on evidence that inflation pass through has been higher than hoped, raising the unpleasant prospect of continued persistence in too-rapid price and wage rises
commentary_lower: UK activity and inflation stagnates in 2025 and more join the dovish contingent, requiring the MPC to bring rates down for a second consecutive meeting to boost economic activity

commentary_central: The BoE will deliver five cuts in 2025 as it eases policy towards a more neutral rate
commentary_higher: Concerns about remaining inflationary pressure leaves the MPC reluctant to significantly relax its stance
commentary_lower: The UK economy weakens significantly, requiring the BoE to stimulate demand

commentary_central: Inflation remains close to target and the bank maintains a more passive position to monitor the economy
commentary_higher: Inflation remains persistently above target forcing the bank to hold rates higher for longer and reconsider estimates of the neutral rate
commentary_lower: Weak growth or an external shock forces the bank to cut rates to stimulate the economy and keep unemployment in check

commentary_central: Inflation remains close to target and the bank maintains a more passive position to monitor the economy
commentary_higher: Inflation remains persistently above target forcing the bank to hold rates higher for longer and reconsider estimates of the neutral rate
commentary_lower: Weak growth or an external shock forces the bank to cut rates to stimulate the economy and keep unemployment in check

commentary_central: Interest rates converge on a rate similar to the expected inflation rate and lower than nominal GDP, due to stronger public finances and lower potential growth rates. The path towards these rates might be bumpy with long periods outside the range. Hence the low probability for a central scenario.
commentary_higher: Stronger growth or a growing lack of confidence in UK public finances would require a higher neutral interest rate. Strong growth because plentiful potential alternative investments allow savers to demand higher returns and weak public finances because government needs to attract more savings.
commentary_lower: Weak growth and persistently low investment generates few outside options for savings, helping the longer-term interest rate to fall to low levels.

commentary_central: Tariffs arrive at the start of April and begin to generate further evidence of lower confidence and output that leads the BoJ to stay on hold
commentary_higher: Tariff impact is weaker than expected or Japan strikes a trade deal with the US or recieves tariffs exemptions allowing the BoJ to raise rates for a secon time this year
commentary_lower: The BoJ lowers rates to respond to economic threats

commentary_central: Services inflation begins to rise and the last piece of the “wage price cycle” is in place leaving the BoJ few option but to raise again
commentary_higher: A very unlikely scenario where the BoJ is forced to raise rates again due to severe yen weakness
commentary_lower: Tariffs are hitting production and confidence and the BoJ remains on hold amid high uncertainty

commentary_central: Wage indications at the end of 2025 are sufficiently strong for the BoJ to take another step towards neutral rates, achieving that goal this year
commentary_higher: The BoJ raises rates faster due to a much weaker yen, or faster growth and stronger indications of a wage-price cycle
commentary_lower: The BoJ assesses that wage growth and inflation are on track and maintains rates with a view to an early rate rise at the start of 2026

commentary_central: The BoJ assesses that wage growth inflation trends are on track following spring wage negotiations and continues to push rates slowly higher
commentary_higher: The BoJ becomes confident that wages and prices will reinforce one another and seeks a faster path towards neutral rates
commentary_lower: The BoJ holds rates in response to weaker wage and inflation developments or increased risks from an external shock such as trade tariffs

commentary_central: The BoJ assesses that wage growth inflation trends are on track and achieves the mid point of our neutral rates range
commentary_higher: The BoJ becomes confident that wages and prices will reinforce one another and seeks a more normal range for interest rates
commentary_lower: The BoJ holds rates lower in response to weaker wage and inflation developments or increased risks from an external shock such as trade tariffs

commentary_central: Interest rates converge on a relatively low neutral rate.
commentary_higher: A successful emergence from decades of weak growth and inflation would require higher neutral interest rates.
commentary_lower: Japan falls back into its low inflation trap, failing to generate domestic inflation and wage growth.
